ygData.subject: Re: [neat] Re: Combining NSGA-II and NEAT speciated fitness sharing
ygData.msgSnippet: Thanks Ken, this is very useful information. I googled for NEAT and NSGA-II but for some reason couldn t find anything.. I did find some more papers this

Subject: Re: [neat] Re: Combining NSGA-II and NEAT speciated fitness sharing
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=234577593; y=e6EWS8frZrpWPEkkTPDps8edg3KaRyQAp0thsDBkhgoaTnP3JKuknQ8-wJJSzEG4VZUaJUrzLA

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=UTF-8
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Thanks Ken, this is very useful information.

I googled for NEAT and NSGA-I=
I but for some reason couldn't find anything..
I did find some more papers =
this morning, however (but not the ones you
linked, I guess Google hasn't i=
ndexed the contents of them yet):

"Multirobot Behavior Synchronization thr=
ough Direct Neural Network
Communication" (David B. D'Ambrosio et al. 2012)=

http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/papers/dambrosio_icira12.pdf
=E2=80=8BThis paper d=
oesn't explain how they combined NEAT and NSGA-II, they simply
say: "Teams =
are trained by HyperNEAT with a multiobjective reward scheme
through NSGAII=
 [32] with three objectives: ..."=E2=80=8B

"Effective Diversity Maintenanc=
e in Deceptive Domains" (J. Lehman, K.
Stanley, R. Miikkulainen. 2013)
http=
://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/papers/lehman_gecco13.pdf
Disables speciation and uses =
explicit genetic diversity objective (Handles
it in the same way as the fir=
st one you linked).

"Evolving Agent Behavior In Multiobjective Domains Usi=
ng Fitness-Based
Shaping" (J. Schrum, R. Miikkulainen. 2010)
http://www.cs.=
utexas.edu/~ai-lab/pubs/schrum.gecco10.pdf
Disables speciation, no genetic =
diversity maintenance (but they do use a
behavioural diversity objective).
=

I think it's probably a good idea to maintain explicit speciation for the
=
benefits it provides (eg more likely viable offspring by mating within
spec=
ies (though this could be achieved without using speciation in a global
par=
ent selection process), protecting innovation within a species based on
a s=
pecies age, fitness sharing).

So I'm leaning towards something like the ap=
proach used in the paper you
were co-author in (Pareto-based evolutionary c=
omputational approach for
wireless sensor placement):

*Foreach generation*=

* Evaluate fitness of entire population (some fitness values would need to=

be recalculated (eg novelty) but not others)*
* Speciate*
* Rank and sort =
population by non-dominance within each species*
* Create offspring from ex=
isting population*
* Select **parents within each species according to rank=
ing*
* Produce **Os** offspring for each species **s*
* Apply mutation oper=
ators*
*Cull all members from population except the top **Es** *within each=

species *s* according to ranking (maintaining elites)
* Add offspring to p=
opulation*

The question is how to determine Os and Es. It seems that what =
we need is a
single scalar value representing an analogue of a species aver=
age fitness
(for fitness sharing) for each species that allows comparing th=
e fitness of
one species to another to determine the number of offspring.

=
As you say, in the above paper the fitness of a member within a species is
=
based on the ranking within the species. Specifically: *"Assuming that a
to=
tal of Y Pareto-ranks are assigned in a species, all organisms at rank X
(w=
here 1 is the most dominating rank, and Y is the least dominating) will
hav=
e the =EF=AC=81tness value 2^(Y-X-1)".* As far as I can tell this doesn't a=
llow
comparing fitness values between species in a meaningful way (correct =
me if
I'm wrong).

Perhaps one approach might be to use a population-wide r=
anking to assign
single scalar fitness values to individuals, which are the=
n adjusted for
fitness sharing in each species, in order to determine Os. T=
he ranking is
then also used within each species to determine parents and e=
lites within
that species (I think the population-wide ranking can be reuse=
d just within
a species, but if necessary a ranking can be redone within ea=
ch species).

=E2=80=8BCheers,
Oliver=E2=80=8B


T: 0421 972 953 | E: olive=
r.coleman@... | W: http://ojcoleman.com



On 14 June 2013 08:07, Ken=
 <kstanley@...> wrote:

> **
>
>
>
>
> Hi Oliver,
>
> The best wa=
y to combine NEAT with NSGA-II (or multiobjective optimization
> in general=
) is an open question, but there have been a few precedents that
> seemed t=
o work. Given the utility of having multiple objectives, it is
> indeed an =
important question. It's true that the main problem is that it is
> not cle=
ar how speciation should interact with the non-dominated fronts.
>
> Our gr=
oup recently has tried simply replacing NEAT-style speciation with a
> "gen=
etic diversity objective." The benefit of that approach is that you
> don't=
 have to worry about the interaction between speciation and the pareto
> fr=
ont while you still get some protection for genetic diversity; the
> downsi=
de of course is it's not certain that the dynamics will be exactly
> like f=
itness sharing. But you can see an example of this approach in this
> paper=
:
>
> http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/papers/lehman_ab13.pdf
>
> The genetic divers=
ity objective is defined there as: "In particular, the
> genomic diversity =
of a given genome is quantifi ed as the average distance
> to its k-nearest=
 neighbors in genotype space as measured by NEAT's genomic
> distance measu=
re."
>
> Of course, the approach you are suggesting is different and would =
preserve
> fitness sharing. I actually was co-author on a paper that tried =
to do
> something like that a while ago, and you can see it here:
>
> http:=
//www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0952197610001442
>
> In this p=
aper (if I can remember correctly) I believe the pareto-ranking
> is comput=
ed within each NEAT species and a single fitness score (that can
> then be =
modified by fitness sharing) is assigned to each individual based
> on pare=
to-rank.
>
> I think that differs a bit from the options you are considerin=
g, but at
> least it provides some context and seemed also to work okay. I =
need to
> think more on what is actually the best way to combine these meth=
ods
> because right now I'm not sure what is really best, but it seems ther=
e are
> multiple ways you could go that are at least viable. The main thing=
 is to
> make sure that no matter what you do, you don't lose the ability t=
o protect
> genetic diversity.
>
> Joel might have more comment since he's =
played with the genetic diversity
> objective (the first approach I mentoin=
ed) himself.
>
> Best,
>
> ken
>
>
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Oliver Co=
leman <oliver.coleman@...> wrote:
> >
> > Hi all,
> >
> > I have another im=
plementation kind of question (I was hoping I would
> > realise the answer =
once I wrote it out, but that didn't happen!):
> >
> > I'm implementing the=
 NSGA-II multi-objective EA method in my (Hyper)NEAT
> > software (https://=
github.com/OliverColeman/ahni). I'd like to continue
> > using speciation a=
nd fitness sharing (according to species). It seems I
> > need to try and m=
erge the NEAT algorithm and the NSGA-II algorithm, which
> > comes down to =
something like:
> >
> > Evaluate fitness of entire population
> > Speciate
=
> > Foreach generation
> > Create offspring from existing population
> > Se=
lect parents (using speciated fitness)
> > Reproduce
> > Apply mutation ope=
rators
> > Add offspring to population (NOTE: the population size is now te=
mporarily
> > bigger than the desired size)
> > Evaluate fitness of entire =
population (some fitness values would need to
> be
> > recalculated (eg nov=
elty) but not others)
> > Speciate
> > Rank and sort population by non-domi=
nance *(**separately within each
> > species? If not then **using original =
fitness OR shared fitness as
> > determined by speciation?)*
>
> > Cull pop=
ulation by successively removing lowest ranked sets (within each
> > specie=
s) until the desired pop size is reached (is slightly more
> > complicated =
than this)
> >
> > I'm wondering first whether it would be best to do the r=
anking and
> sorting
> > separately within each species, and if not then is=
 it a good idea to use
> > speciated fitness (as determined by NEAT) when r=
anking and sorting.
> >
> > If not ranking and sorting separately within ea=
ch species, then a reason
> > for using speciated fitness when ranking and =
sorting is that speciated
> > fitness sharing helps protect innovation and =
the ranking and sorting
> > determines which members of the population (whi=
ch at this point includes
> > the previous population and the new offspring=
) will remain for the next
> > generation. A possible reason against is tha=
t it might "skew" the results
> > of the ranking and sorting procedure (whi=
ch is intended to find the
> "real"
> > Pareto fronts/sets). Perhaps as lon=
g as the elites (according to each
> > objective) are maintained in a speci=
es then it doesn't matter much one
> way
> > or the other.
> >
> > (Note th=
at there are two selection stages being employed: the one to
> select
> > p=
arents to produce offspring (which I think should be the same as that
> for=

> > NEAT: mating within species, etc), and the one to reduce the populatio=
n,
> > after adding offspring to it, to the desired population size).
> >
>=
 > I hope the above makes sense, let me know if anything is ambiguous, etc.=

> > Thanks in advance for any advice!
> >
> > Cheers,
> > Oliver
> >
> > T=
: 0421 972 953 | E: oliver.coleman@... | W: http://ojcoleman.com
> >
>
>  
=
>

--089e01160bba82abcb04df1420ac

Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

 <span dir=3D"ltr"><<a href=3D"mailto:kstanley@..." target=3D"=

<u></u>










<div>
<span>=C2=A0</span>


<div>
  <div>


    <div=
>
      
      
      <p><br>
<br>
Hi Oliver, <br>
<br>
The best way to com=
bine NEAT with NSGA-II (or multiobjective optimization in general) is an op=
en question, but there have been a few precedents that seemed to work.  Giv=
en the utility of having multiple objectives, it is indeed an important que=
stion.  It's true that the main problem is that it is not clear how spe=
ciation should interact with the non-dominated fronts.  <br>


<br>
Our gro=
up recently has tried simply replacing NEAT-style speciation with a "g=
enetic diversity objective."  The benefit of that approach is that you=
 don't have to worry about the interaction between speciation and the p=
areto front while you still get some protection for genetic diversity; the =
downside of course is it's not certain that the dynamics will be exactl=
y like fitness sharing.  But you can see an example of this approach in thi=
s paper:<br>


<br>
<a href=3D"http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/papers/lehman_ab13.p=
df" target=3D"_blank">http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/papers/lehman_ab13.pdf</a><br=
>
<br>
The genetic diversity objective is defined there as: "In partic=
ular, the genomic diversity of a given genome is quantifi=0Ced as the avera=
ge distance to its k-nearest neighbors in genotype space as measured by NEA=
T's genomic distance measure."<br>


<br>
Of course, the approach =
you are suggesting is different and would preserve fitness sharing.  I actu=
ally was co-author on a paper that tried to do something like that a while =
ago, and you can see it here:<br>
<br>
<a href=3D"http://www.sciencedirect.=
com/science/article/pii/S0952197610001442" target=3D"_blank">http://www.sci=
encedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0952197610001442</a><br>
<br>
In this p=
aper (if I can remember correctly) I believe the pareto-ranking is computed=
 within each NEAT species and a single fitness score (that can then be modi=
fied by fitness sharing) is assigned to each individual based on pareto-ran=
k. <br>


<br>
I think that differs a bit from the options you are consider=
ing, but at least it provides some context and seemed also to work okay.  I=
 need to think more on what is actually the best way to combine these metho=
ds because right now I'm not sure what is really best, but it seems the=
re are multiple ways you could go that are at least viable.  The main thing=
 is to make sure that no matter what you do, you don't lose the ability=
 to protect genetic diversity.<br>


<br>
Joel might have more comment sinc=
e he's played with the genetic diversity objective (the first approach =
I mentoined) himself.<br>
<br>
